Program_Issues_Addressed: The primary objective of this program is to develop the resilience of young people facing multiple, complex and intersecting issues.  The Studio is an inclusive, youth-driven drop-in centre for 13 to 21-year-olds that openly celebrates LGBTQ+ youth, and attracts a diverse population from across the GTA. The young people who find their way to The Studio are marginalized for various reasons: mental health and substance use; social issues; stigma and isolation associated with identifying as LGBTQ+; and/or coming from a racialized or low income background.
Program_Practice_Model_Notes: The goal of this program is to build a stronger sense of community among different youth and provide opportunities for youth to engage more fully with trusted adults and peers.  This is grounded in the model we have developed for an inclusive, integrated, safe space, for all youth which also prioritizes the needs of LGBTTQ youth. Another key principle is the involvement of youth in every aspect of the program decision making providing them with opportunities to develop social, life and leadership skills.
Program_Outcomes_Notes: The outcomes we have identified include:  An increase in key resilience measures such as the presence of a positive adult relationship and supportive peers, A positive sense of identity Improved access to necessary resources both material resources and social services Improved sense of community reflected by improved social participation/engagement
Outcomes1: 5 - Ontario youth have at least one consistent caring adult in their lives
Outcomes2: 20 - Ontario youth know about and easily navigate resources in their communities
Outcomes3: 17 - Ontario youth are engaged in their communities

Program_Issues_Addressed: Children and youth in this low-income, high poverty, high crime, ethno-culturally diverse neighbourhood are at-risk for mental and emotional issues but some of these problems can be off-set by participating in a sports and recreation program like ours. We provide a safe place for inner city children and youth to hang out after school where they can play sports and get exercise, use the computers for recreation or schoolwork, arts and crafts, dance, music and a variety of other activities. We believe all children and youth should have access to recreational activities and we provide it free. We also provide healthy snacks and have a cooking program where kids can learn to make simple recipes.
Program_Practice_Model_Notes: Arts- based
Program_Outcomes_Notes: To open their minds to see that they have many possibilities and opportunities. To be encouraged /inspired to take school seriously and go on to post secondary education. Develop mentoring and leadership ability and encourage older participants to volunteer and later work in our program. Increase mental and physical well-being and develop social and academic skills that increase chances of success in school and work.
Outcomes1: 7 - Ontario youth achieve academic success
Outcomes2: 1 - Ontario youth are physically healthy
Outcomes3: 17 - Ontario youth are engaged in their communities
Program_Funder: United Way of Hamilton and Burlington, Rotary Club Hamilton and a number of smaller grants from various sources (RBC, HCF...)

Name_Program: We are a youth serving agency, so all of our programs and services are youth specific.
Program_Issues_Addressed: We are a community health agency serving the needs of youth in Toronto. We provide accessible and inclusive programs and services that promote healthy sexuality and informed decision-making. We believe in supporting the whole person. To do so, we offer primary, sexual and reproductive, and mental health services for youth. We conduct community based research to answer questions and identify assets, gaps and barriers to improve our services. And to give youth the skills and information they need to make informed choices about all aspects of their health, we provide customized programming, such as workshops, peer education, and ongoing sessions.
Program_Practice_Model_Notes: Clinical health services, mental health services, peer programming, health promotion, workshops

Name_Program: We have so many individual programs under Children and Youth services and they are offered in differernt locations acrosss the GTA
Contact_Name: Janice Tsoi (Program Manager of Immigrant Youth Center in York Region); Connie Leung (PM of Community Services in Toronto)
Program_Issues_Addressed: academic, cultural, economic, and social integration in the local communities.
Program_Practice_Model_Notes: CICS uses a welcoming and asset-building approach to provide immigrant youth a space for positive development and social integration. Our innovative programming is based on the Five Cs Model (i.e., competence, confidence, connection, character, caring/compassion) to prepare immigrant youth to contribute positively to their schools and families, and the community they live in. Targeting youth between the ages of 13 and 24, CICS provides one-on-one supportive counselling, orientation programs and a range of 5Cs building workshops and activities. Besides addressing their settlement needs, we aim to help them excel and succeed in Canada. Examples of service activities include needs and assets assessment, skills and knowledge building, mentorship, leadership training, career path building, positive identity building, and community engagement.
Program_Outcomes_Notes: ƒ?› Youth play an active role in identifying their needs, goals and assets to develop their action plans. ƒ?› Youth are able to access settlement and other youth services offered by CICSƒ??s Immigrant Youth Centre and Immigrant Resource Centre. ƒ?› Youth are made aware of other youth services available in the community. ƒ?› Youth indicate increased understanding of the self and knowledge of the Canadian system to access community resources that meet their needs. ƒ?› Youth will acquire the confidence, connection, competence, character, and compassion they need to fully integrate in local communities.  ƒ?› Youth obtain peer and professional support they need to cope with the challenges in their transition in life.
Outcomes1: 20 - Ontario youth know about and easily navigate resources in their communities
Program_Funder: IRCC, MCIIT, UWTYR, OTF, and private donors.

Name_Program: We offer numerous youth program; youth at risk, harm reduction programs, newcomer specific, employment, leadership development
Program_Issues_Addressed: The scope of our programs is quite broad. The overarching theme is building a healthy and inclusive community. We do this various levels of health and fitness programs, community based programs and government funded programs. Each program addresses key objectives but collectively feed the common thread of health and inclusiveness.  We use the pillars of Asset Development to guide our measurable outcomes and program design.
Program_Practice_Model_Notes: As mentioned previously Asset Development is the over arching model. The more assets a youth/individual has the greater chance for "success". Depending on program there could be group work/team building and/or individual counselling. One of our greatest strengths is our ability to engage our community partners. As an example, our Employment and Newcomer office houses 20+ programs being delivered by 8 different agencies. Each agency plays an integral role in moving the youth/individual along the employment and/or settlement continuum; Wrap around affect.
Program_Outcomes_Notes: This is not easy to answer and would take a great deal of time to list all outcomes as there a numerous programs, each with its own set of outcomes.

Program_Issues_Addressed: Support of youth in linguistically and cultural manner.Sexual health, well being and supports around dealing with HIV diagnosis and challenges that come with it.Education around safer sex practices for the infected and affected youth,use of art therapy , one on one peer support, support groups and other techniques to address issues of self esteem, self-stigma, and stigma and discrimination as a whole.Support youth around HIV disclosure and its impact on their health and well being.
Program_Practice_Model_Notes: The program teaches them that HIV is not who they are ƒ?? it is just an infection they have. And that they are human beings with inner and unlimited strengths and potential. The aim of the Self Discovery intervention is to provide newly diagnosed young people with a range of practical skills including goal setting, effective communication and negotiation skills. use  of  self assessment , journaling,expressive arts therapy to enhance their emotional well being, and improve on treatment adherence and selfcare .use of  Role play, individual and group exercises too.
Program_Outcomes_Notes: we, have successful strategies for self growth, assessing self, deal with loss process, SMART Goals principles, implementing a action plan, use of mantraƒ??s and journaling, breaking the silence and HIV disclosure.  In the end the clients  exhibit increased self confidence; increased awareness of self and HIV; improved communication skills and self confidence to discuss their HIV status with family and friends; improved treatment adherence , improved health and are now more focused on other stuff/challenges  rather than on self.  eventually they are able to deal with their other challenges e.g. sexuality disclosing sexual orientation to friends and family etc .
Outcomes1: 13 - Ontario youth experience social inclusion and value diversity
Outcomes2: 2 - Ontario youth feel mentally healthy
Program_Funder: AIDS BUREAU ontario ministry of health and long term care

Name_Program: Youth Exchanges, Aboriginal Youth Leadership Program, Global Learner, EQWiP HUBs
Program_Issues_Addressed: Youth need to acquire essential knowledge, skills and attitudes for the transition to adulthood, as well as prepare them to be productive, socially-conscious and contributing members of their communities, and potentially capable of being agents of change. Building on established theories of transformative and experiential learning, CWY  programs create an experience of discovery for young people, facilitated by a safe and supportive environment, and employing adult allies to facilitate critical reflection,  analysis and skill acquisition.
Program_Practice_Model_Notes: Reciprocal Youth Exchanges  relies on a counterpart model to transmit skills, competencies, and knowledge. CWY Educational Model occupies a middle-ground between formal education and informal education and is grounded in various theoretical models, namely community-based, learner-based and asset-based approaches.  EQWiP HUBs connect motivated young Canadians and international youth in a peer-to-peer model. Aboriginal Youth Leadership Program model integrates Aboriginal knowledge and culture into all program components, including training, orientation, selection of communities and partners, development of educational materials, monitoring and evaluation.
Program_Outcomes_Notes: 1. youth acquire  knowledge, skills and attitudes referred to as transferable or life skills, including intercultural and interpersonal communication  skills, critical thinking, teamwork, etc.. 2. the expansion of youth's social networks, CWY's programs purposely expand the social capital of youth and their communities, which can in turn increase their "collective capacity to engage effectively in leadership roles and processes" (MacCauley and Douglas, 1998). 3. to increase targeted communitiesƒ?? human and social assets by increasing the ability of young women and young men to lead sustainable livelihood activities and engage in decision-making processes in communities and institutions..
Outcomes1: 13 - Ontario youth experience social inclusion and value diversity
Outcomes2: 6 - Ontario form and maintain healthy
Outcomes3: 17 - Ontario youth are engaged in their communities
Program_Funder: Global Affairs Canada

Name_Program: Youth Job Connection, JobStart, Career Focus, Boot Camp, Career Sampler, InSight-Youth Mentoring Partnership
Program_Issues_Addressed: KEYS has been delivering youth employment programs for over 35 years in the Kingston and surrounding communities. We offer support to help youth make informed career and education decisions, gain employability skills through pre-employment training and on-the-job training. Our focus is on two groups of youth; youth at-risk and facing barriers to employment, and recent post-secondary grads who need support to transition into a professional work place setting related to their field of study. We want our youth to  combination of paid work placements, career coaching, mentorship, and information about postsecondary education and training opportunities in order to make informed decisions and gain labour market attachment. The underlying issues we address through our innovative programs are the foundational building blocks of helping people reach their full potential. At the same time we support economic development and community capacity building.
Program_Practice_Model_Notes: We take a stenghts based assessment approach to our wotk with youth clients, focussing on assests and interests, skills development.  We prioritize service coordination and a strong belief system that people can and do change and want to reach thier potential.
Program_Outcomes_Notes: Employment or enhanced employability Training completion or continued education
Outcomes1: 7 - Ontario youth achieve academic success
Outcomes2: 10 - Ontario youth have opportunities for meaningful employment opportunities
Program_Funder: various levels of government

Program_Issues_Addressed: Youth Job Link, launching in spring 2016, is designed to help youth, including students, aged 15 to 29, who do not face significant barriers to employment, but who could benefit from some extra help to plan their careers and transition to the labour market.   Youth Job Link will provide three categories of non-intensive employment services, each of which will be available year-round. They are:  Career exploration services to increase knowledge of career options and support career decision-making; Career management services to improve readiness for the labour market; and, Job search, readiness and matching assistance to connect youth with employers offering employment opportunities, including summer jobs.

Program_Issues_Addressed: employment
Program_Practice_Model_Notes: Youth Job Link is for youth who do not face significant barriers.  Youth with significant barriers are referred out to other employment programs such as Skills Link or Youth Job Connection.  Youth Job Link supports youth under 30 to find full or part time work while in school, or between semesters, or when they have left school completely.  We match youth to employer needs.  We can offer small incentives to employers and also small financial supports to clients.  We assess you based on their motivation to find work, and their service need.  Youth with lower motivation may benefit from a motivational interviewing appointment.

Program_Issues_Addressed: The Youth Outreach program addresses the need to break the cycle of violence and abuse through early intervention.  Identifying young women who are living with abuse and/or at-risk of being victimized is a recognized strategy while targeting young men with the aim of engaging them as allies in a gender-based equality movement. Provide early interventions with young men and women to equip them with knowledge regarding gender based violence and strategies to manage challenges will result in better choices and positive futures.
Program_Practice_Model_Notes: The Youth Outreach component of the program has been offered by Abrigo for the past 20 years in collaboration with the Toronto District School Board (TDSB) and the Toronto District Catholic School Board (TDCSB).  Through public education, this youth program supports the larger goal of having participants experience life and relationships that are free of violence and abuse and help build a supportive caring community that does not tolerate such actions.   Youth Outreach Objectives: - To provide youth with accurate information regarding community resources and how to seek support - To improve knowledge among youth regarding gender-based violence and abuse issues - To improve stress coping strategies  - To enhance youth leadership skills   Individual Youth Counselling Objectives: - To increase knowledge of abuse and impact on self - To develop a safety plan - Ensure access to information promoting informed decisions. - To improve self-esteem - Ensure that urgent needs are met - To access essential resources (such as housing, OW, substance abuse counselling) - To improve inter-familial relationships
Program_Outcomes_Notes: At the conclusion of their involvement with the Youth Outreach component of the program, we want to see evidence that youth have gained new knowledge and skills.  Participant surveys are administered to measure the extent to which they report back on any new knowledge that they have acquired and whether they intend to put what they have learned into practice.  With Individual Counselling, outcomes are recorded when mutually agreed upon between Counsellor and youth.  In support of Abrigoƒ??s efforts to mitigate the effects of poverty, the following outcomes were tracked for the fiscal year as evidence this programƒ??s impact upon a total of 1,350 youth served:  100% surveyed reported having knowledge regarding where to seek help if and when needed 100% surveyed reported new knowledge regarding gender-based violence and abuse 72% surveyed reported improved stress coping strategies  36% surveyed reported enhanced leadership skills as a result of TAG-V outreach  84 youth reported understanding their options and making informed decisions through counselling  46 youth reported decreased social isolation as a result of counselling 77 youth reported making progress towards attaining their personal goals through counselling 76 youth reported increased coping strategy skills as a result of counselling
Outcomes1: 2 - Ontario youth feel mentally healthy
Program_Funder: City of Toronto & United Way

Program_Issues_Addressed: Towards our goal of socially integrated and empowered individuals, we offer youth outreach to the schools providing workshops on topics related to dating violence and mental health and wellbeing as well as individual counselling. Our individual counselling services are for youth who are experiencing dating violence/gender violence/family violence/bullying/mental health and substance abuse issues.
Program_Practice_Model_Notes: Practice model in a group setting at school can vary by topic and generally is interactive, and / or arts based. Individual counselling is generally based on the narrative therapy model, and can also incorporate CBT, and arts based approached depending on individual and their goals.
Program_Outcomes_Notes: Our Youth Outreach in schools has the outcome to increase awareness and knowledge of gender based violence, in all its forms, and strategies and or resources for youth. Our individual counselling services is to increase safety for the client and discuss options and updating an action plan based upon their individual needs and goals.
Outcomes1: 15 - Ontario youth respect and are respected by the law and justice system
Program_Funder: City of Toronto, Ministry of Children and Youth Services and Canadian Women's Foundation
